title: Basics of UK Conveyancing Law
headline: Get familiar with the key legal aspects of buying or selling a property and land with this free online course.
description: To own a property, land or a house is a dream come true for many people. Due to the sensitive nature of the process, there are legal rules that govern and safeguard all parties involved. The importance of this is well emphasised in UK law where there is a whole legal branch referred to as conveyancing that covers the acquisition and disposal of real estate. This short course explores the key legal aspects of conveyancing in the United Kingdom.
courseDescription:
Conveyancing is a branch of law that deals with property and land acquisition. This course explains the principles of conveyancing, different types of conveyance, and important conveyancing essentials. We will also distinguish between a solicitor and a conveyancer. Find out what makes a good conveyancer and the steps in the conveyancing process.

Property law can be used as a guide to deal with issues surrounding property. We will spend some time talking about several types of property law and how important each one is. The concept of land law, co-ownership, leases, the law of mortgages, and much more is also covered. Then we will teach you about contract law so that you can learn how an offer is communicated and be able to tell an offer from a simple invitation to treat. The acceptance and rejection of offers will also be unpacked. Additionally, you will learn the fundamental accounting practices needed to handle conveyancing transactions.

The course will teach you how to draft both registered and unregistered titles. Concepts such as barring requisitions, drafting a contract for the sale of an unregistered title, and drafting a transfer of a registered title are also discussed. Finally, we will discuss tax issues that pertain to conveyancers, such as capital gains tax and stamp duty land tax. By the end, you should have a good grasp of the basics of UK conveyancing law. This course provides you with a springboard, whether you want to begin a career in conveyancing or you simply want to be knowledgeable about the foundations of conveyancing as an estate agent, for example. Click the enrol button to get started now!

Start Course Now

slides:
• Learning Outcomes

  • Having completed this module, you will be able to:
    • Define conveyancing and list the types of conveyances.
    • Distinguish between a solicitor and a conveyancer. 
    • Identify different types of conveyancing services, processes, and costs.
    • Explain property law and recognise different types of property laws.
    • Discuss land law and the law of mortgages.
    • Analyse the basis of contract laws.
    • Describe the landlord and property manager relationship.
    • List the stages of residential conveyancing.
    • State the three-digit account code structure.
    • Outline the way of drafting registered and unregistered titles.
    • Evaluate all kinds of tax-related issues in conveyancing.

  • Lesson Summary

    • Conveyancing is the legal process that starts when your offer on a house or other property is accepted and ends when you receive the keys.
    • A contract is normally drafted by a solicitor acting on behalf of the seller once the parties have decided to proceed with the acquisition.
    • Land law is concerned with land rights in or over land and the processes whereby those rights and interests are created and transferred.
    • A contract is a promise enforceable by law. The aim of the law of contract is to make sure that the agreements are made fairly.
    • The relationship between a property manager and a landlord is a legal relationship based on the law of the agency.
    • Seller's conveyancer prepares the draft contract and supporting contract documentation. 
    • Buyer's conveyancer prepares a draft transfer deed and completion information form and sends these to the seller's conveyancer for completion.
    • Mortgages are a claim or lien placed on the buyer's real estate by the lender as security for money borrowed.
    • It is essential to re-read the evidence of the title and the agreement for sale in order to draft any purchase deed.
    • Three forms of taxation are likely to be relevant in a domestic conveyancing transaction.
